William Shakespeare.Action: Is described as a haunted man, silently standing amidst the ruins of The Globe Theatre after the fire.
Barely notices an 11-year-old frail boy watching him in the country tavern, showing a lack of engagement or attention.
Ignores the Boy who asks him to finish a story, shows impatience and irritation.
Looks back after ignoring the Boy, noticing the Boy has gone, and inquires about him to the Landlady.
Looks blankly when asked when he will return to London, showing a lack of decisiveness or clarity.
Accepts Anne's admonishment in silence and quietly retreats, indicating passivity and inability to address family concerns effectively.
Reflects silently by the fire and contemplates the countryside, suggesting introspection and thoughtful awareness.
Attempts to return to physical labor by digging but quickly gives it up, laying aside his spade and walking away.
Engages in light, witty banter with Susanna, showing awareness of financial security (mentions buying a pension) and self-deprecating humor about longevity.
Expresses a deep sense of having lost touch with reality, admitting he has lived too long in imaginary worlds and suggesting possible disengagement from current realities.
Does not respond when Susanna asks if he will write no more, either not hearing or choosing not to answer, indicating avoidance or reluctance to commit.
Reflects on his past hardships with insight and pride, expressing love for his children and their qualities.
Engages in gardening, a difficult physical task, showing persistence and care for his environment.
Struggles to adjust to a new setting with different social expectations (missing church attendance).
Tries to maintain cheerful family demeanor while dealing with internal sadness.
Engages John Hall with a gentle, witty reply showing good nature and a light-hearted, friendly manner.
Works steadily and patiently in his garden, making slow but steady progress with deliberate care.
Responds cleverly and confidently to John Hall's accusation that he is distracting the mob with plays, turning the argument into a witty, gentle rejoinder.
Considers John's words thoughtfully before replying, indicating reflective intelligence and self-possession.
Considers John Hall's appeal to lend his influential voice to their cause regarding the Vicar of Holy Trinity.
Remains silent and avoids answering Judith's probing and accusatory questions about family tragedy.
Attempts to defend himself by stating he never gave cause or said unkind words to Judith.
Fails to effectively communicate or resolve tension with his daughter Judith, who expresses bitterness and accusation.
Is confronted by Anne pointing out his skill in putting words into others' mouths but failing to use words effectively with his own family.
Dismisses Henry's repeated attempts to ask questions with curt, minimal answers and quickly ends the conversation.
Shows some tolerance by listening briefly and not outright rejecting Henry despite impatience.
Sits quietly reading his son Hamnet’s verses, smiles warmly at a touching line.
Attempts to greet the Lucy family as equals at church but is rebuffed, feels pained and embarrassed.
Reads his son Hamnet’s verse carefully and treasures the pages, showing thoughtful engagement with his work.
Attempts to greet the Lucy family as equals during church but is met with curt dismissal, appearing pained and embarrassed.
Observes social interactions attentively during church service, noticing exchanges between Susanna, Rafe Smith, and Hall.
Shows internal discomfort and embarrassment when treated dismissively by Sir Thomas Lucy, indicating social vulnerability.
Stunned and red faced with anger and shame witnessing public slander against his daughter Susanna.
Discusses the slander case calmly with Anne and attempts a direct confrontation with John Lane to understand and address the issue.
Attempts to reason with John Lane by talking about the play 'Titus Andronicus' and its impact, showing awareness of his adversary's views and using his own work as leverage.
Does not take any visible aggressive legal steps himself but relies on the court process to handle John Lane’s slander externally.
Describes a fierce protector who loves his daughter and would defend her fiercely.
Admits to telling exaggerated stories to John Lane, prioritizing a good story over strict truth.
Shares a light moment with Anne, leading to a small thaw in her coldness.
Confidently tells an intense story about a fierce man who loved his daughter and would defend her fiercely.
Admits to embellishing stories to make them more compelling (telling John Lane a fabricated story).
Shows awareness of human fears and uses this insight to engage and influence others (comments on fear of the unknown).
Reflects on the coldness between Susanna and John Hall with understanding, recognizing mutual recognition of fault.
Uses voice-over to convey sympathy and insight into Susanna's loneliness and struggle.
Defends Susanna’s reputation against slander, choosing to protect her rather than respond to Judith’s provocative insinuation.
Remains silent when Judith confronts him with uncomfortable family truths, possibly indicating emotional restraint or avoidance.
Shows confusion and slight discomfort when Susanna challenges his assumptions about her marriage and personal insight.
Shares deeply personal poetry with Southampton, expressing sincere and exclusive affection.
Reassures Southampton with loving words, calling him beautiful and affirming their bond.
Confidently asserts his personal achievements like money, houses, and Coat of Arms, demonstrating self-sufficiency and success.
Engages in a deep and heartfelt exchange with Southampton, showing emotional intelligence and poetic skill.
Uses his poetry to sincerely express feelings, indicating skillful use of language and personal authenticity.
Admits his works were meant only for Southampton, showing a focused and deliberate artistic intention.
Expresses hope that his feelings might be reciprocated by Southampton, despite social boundaries.
Is crushed but remains dignified and does not retaliate or become bitter after Southampton's cold rejection.
Attempts gentle encouragement to Judith about marriage and children, wishing comfort and companionship for her.
Grows irritated and somewhat angry at Judith’s negativity and resistance, culminating in an outburst with fist on table.
Absorbs a harsh remark from Judith about replacing his deceased son and tries to respond reasonably.
Responds to family tension with attempts at reason and normality, tries to provide comfort and perspective regarding marriage and children.
Ignores subtle jibes initially and keeps composure, showing social tact and awareness.
Becomes irritated and eventually explodes in anger with fist on table during family discussion.
Absorbs a harsh comment from daughter Judith and tries to respond reasonably rather than retaliate immediately.
Displays a lack of emotional control when anger 'slowly boils' and culminates in outburst.
Initially defends the idea that Hamnet wrote the verses, showing confidence in his perception.
Fails to recognize the truth that Judith created the verses and Hamnet was not a poet, showing a form of self-delusion.
Observes Judith burn the papers without intervening, indicating a level of resignation or acceptance rather than taking action to save them.
Shows capacity to listen and slowly come to terms with a painful truth after contradictions from family.
Listens silently to Anne’s painful feelings about their marriage and his absence, showing some unawareness.
Begins to understand his insensitivity regarding Judith’s loyalty to Hamnet and the burning of her verses.
Admits to Susanna that he is a fool for Judith burning her verses, implying regret and self-criticism.
Avoids initially answering Susanna’s question about why he writes no more, showing emotional avoidance.
Admits he is a poor gardener and finds it easier to create things with words.
Smiles and accepts Anne's help with the garden.
Reflects on his son Hamnet’s potential and his own understanding of love versus ambition with thoughtful insight.
Works together with Anne in the garden, listens to her about community matters.
Expresses concern about John and Puritan friends affecting business.
Works collaboratively and positively with Anne in the garden, engaging in thoughtful conversation about local business and social matters.
Expresses concern about Puritan opposition potentially threatening business interests, showing awareness of social and political challenges.
Gifts Anne a specific piece of furniture to keep and remember him by, hoping she will smile and think of him.
Makes a lighthearted, inclusive speech at the wedding feast, acknowledging family flaws with humor and honesty.
Shares a smile with Susanna during the speech, indicating friendly and warm family rapport.
Expresses pride in his family despite past losses; acknowledges common grief in the community; shows good-natured warmth by celebrating family and community with cheers and mutual respect.
Shows sensitivity to family hardships and encourages others (Tom and John) warmly to pursue their business; emphasizes importance of family.
Acknowledges past family difficulties but confidently claims to have brought credit to his hometown.
Proudly emphasizes the importance of family and publicly supports the younger generation to take responsibility.
Fails to conceal or somewhat awkwardly addresses the loss of a son and the impact on his family, causing embarrassment to his daughter.
Expresses tender concern upon learning Judith is pregnant ('Oh my sweet girl').
Is present and engaged in family gatherings, sharing in laughter with Judith and Quiney.
Asks about the absent John Hall, showing attentiveness to family matters.
Expresses sadness and acknowledges John's empathy regarding Judith's distress
Amends his Will, striking out provisions for his new son-in-law after the scandal
Amends his Will carefully in response to personal and family events, showing thoughtful management of his affairs.
Signs his Will solemnly, exhibiting seriousness and awareness of consequences.
Feels the weight of family shame due to Quiney's scandal but does not act impulsively or destructively, reflecting control and composure.
Shows sadness and emotional vulnerability openly but remains composed in difficult family situations.
Compliments his wife Anne's wisdom and decency, showing respect and appreciation.
Calls after Sir Thomas with a sharp comment about wishing he had poached his deer, indicating hostility.
Pauses before leaving Anne working alone in the garden, possibly indicating emotional distance or internal conflict.
Observes children playing and contemplates his lost son with visible sadness.
Visits his deceased son's grave and spends time in quiet reflection and prayer in church.
Expresses skepticism and distance towards organized religion, yet maintains respectful tone.
Remembers and cherishes his late son Hamnet with a special gift and ongoing tender acts, like cutting quills imagining his son’s hand.
Quietly questions Anne about Hamnet's cause of death, showing hesitance and vulnerability.
Observes the silence and tear of Judith without pressuring or blaming, indicating sensitivity.
Uses careful observation of grave records and plague statistics to question the official cause of Hamnet's death, showing analytical thinking.
Struggles to openly confront Anne about Hamnet's death, indicating emotional difficulty in pursuing a painful truth.
Stares hard at Anne, heart in torment after hearing of Hamnet’s death.
Does not verbally express grief or comfort others openly, showing restraint and internalized pain.
Laughs with Jonson despite the harsh truth of the conversation, showing good-natured acceptance.
Responds to Jonson's teasing and criticisms with gentle humor and tolerance.
Acknowledges conflict in personal life (strained relationship with Anne) but remains composed and does not lash out.
Receives high praise from Jonson for his plays, demonstrating recognition of his skill and legacy.
Has a playful and bold moment putting mustard on ham and making a public joke, showing confidence and wit.
Invites Judith to the pub quietly, showing a casual and inclusive social behavior.
Despite being drunk, he takes part in carrying and placing the Coat of Arms in the tavern, symbolizing a proud and confident gesture.
Openly acknowledges and embraces his humble origins and family situation in front of others, showing self-awareness and honesty but possibly risking reputation.
Admits publicly that he worked too hard, drank too little, and worried too much about others’ opinions, showing self-awareness and perseverance.
Acknowledges neglecting his family and expecting too much from his son, demonstrating insight into personal flaws but also emotional intelligence.
Claims authorship of 37 plays, all works of absolute genius except possibly one, expressing confidence in his professional skill.
Makes a self-deprecating statement that he is not a gentleman, showing humility and realistic self-assessment.
Smiles appreciatively at Anne’s beautiful handwriting when signing the marriage license, revealing attentiveness and valuing craftsmanship.
Takes pleasure in attention from strangers, showing openness and engagement.
Feels like a stranger at home despite respect on the street, indicating emotional distance.
Refuses to give words of inspiration to boys, instead tells them to seek money and property.
Expresses desire to create a special garden for deceased son Hamnet, showing sentimental side.
Dismissive to Anne’s comment about garden for Hamnet, implying emotional withdrawal.
Takes pride in being respected by others and acknowledges his reputation confidently.
Hesitates and initially refuses to speak to the boys, then gives a practical but somewhat superficial message about money instead of inspiration.
Suggests creating a special garden as a personal, thoughtful gesture to cope with grief.
Enjoys simple pleasures outdoors and shares a light, mildly playful conversation about his work with Anne.
Shows grief and internalizes mourning but does not openly express emotions; Anne interprets his mourning as self-centered.
Engages quietly and somewhat awkwardly with family during dinner, breaking silence but not creating warmth.
Walks through the garden, scouting for a new plan with evident engagement.
Reflects on his past theatrical achievement of moving a wood across a stage, demonstrating confidence and self-awareness.
Expresses deep personal grief and admits that he will 'write no more,' showing emotional vulnerability that may undermine his confidence.
Engages in a tense and awkward conversation with Anne, showing some inability to fully process or articulate his feelings, suggesting internal conflict.
Shares a moment of levity with Susanna, showing light-heartedness and some openness.
Admits to losing sight of what is real and true after living in imaginary worlds, showing self-awareness and sincerity.
Does not respond to Susanna’s question about writing no more, indicating possible emotional withdrawal or avoidance.
Expresses willingness to help John Hall despite personal dislike, 'I try to like him. For Sue’s sake.'
Shows guardedness and reluctance in confiding intentions about his estate, 'I have no intention of leaving my estate to John Hall.'
Demonstrates understanding of social and political nuances when discussing John Hall's attempt to remove Woolmer as Vicar, showing awareness and tact.
Claims to be a good actor and tries to like John Hall for his daughter's sake, indicating conflict between personal feelings and social strategy.
Is momentarily taken aback by Judith's harsh and candid commentary, showing a slight vulnerability or surprise.
Makes a confident statement about his intention not to leave his estate to John Hall, asserting control over his affairs.
Tells Judith she was once a simple, joyful soul, indicating awareness of her change and possible regret or sorrow.
Chooses not to respond when Judith confronts him about their shared grief and her bitterness.
Says to Anne he never gave Judith cause or said an unkind word, showing his intent to be kind despite underlying family tensions.
Internalizes difficult emotions and keeps silence in tense family moments, showing emotional reservation and lack of open comfort.
Encourages Henry to write honestly from his own soul and humanity, advising kindness and sincerity in creativity.
Asks Henry kindly to leave him to mourn if he cannot save his hollyhocks, showing vulnerability and politeness.
Turns his back and refuses to answer Henry’s pressing question about why he stopped writing, ending the conversation abruptly.
Explains thoughtfully and insightfully to Henry that his knowledge comes from self-exploration, imagination, and life experience, showing deep understanding of the creative process.
Demonstrates confidence and clarity in articulating his artistic philosophy, encouraging honesty and authenticity in writing.
Responds to Henry’s probing question about why he stopped writing with silence and then abruptly ends the conversation, withholding an explanation.
Stunned and red faced with anger and shame during public accusation but does not react impulsively or disruptively.
Maintains composure amidst public uproar and serious personal attack on his family.
Mortified by scandal but reacts with determination to defend family honor legally.
Questions Susanna sharply about her husband's intentions, indicating a lack of trust or sensitivity in the moment.
Addresses the family and community’s shame with resolve rather than despair, showing protective sincerity.
Defends his daughter Susanna against slander by confronting John Lane and discussing the issue calmly with Anne.
Shows distrust toward John Lane and his motives, highlighting John Lane’s vices (prefers cakes and ale) and Puritan attitudes.
Responds to the boy (vision of Hamnet) with warmth and eagerness, expressing deep desire to hear his poem and calling out to him tenderly.
Reacts with horror and recoil to the boy as a plague victim, showing pain and distress at the memory.
Engages sincerely with Anne about the vision and his grief.
Does not visibly engage with Judith who is watching and crying quietly from the window.
Works persistently in his garden despite heat and tiredness, showing effort and focus on his project.
Momentarily confused or affected by a vision of his deceased son, showing emotional vulnerability and distraction.
Engages with his son’s memory and listens to the boy’s poem with expressed desire and care.
Reacts with horror and recoiling to the vision of the plague victim, demonstrating emotional turmoil rather than control.
Offers a sombre family meal, tries to engage with Judith despite tension.
Responds to Judith's accusations by asking for respect and urging her to honour their deceased son.
Scolds Judith harshly telling her to 'hold your tongue' and criticizes her lifestyle.
Encourages Judith to live up to the memory of her brother, urging diligence and goodness.
Shows thoughtful, contemplative behavior alone, reflecting on family tensions.
Maintains composure and tries to reason with Judith despite her harsh words and criticisms; attempts to guide her towards living up to their son's memory and encourages diligence.
Appears burdened and somber; struggles with his relationship with Judith and is preparing to 'eat humble pie,' indicating some personal or relational failure.
Quietly gets on with building the garden thoughtfully, showing persistence and reflection over time.
Rushes in excitedly to share news about the Earl of Southampton's visit.
Dismisses Anne’s concerns about the sonnets and their impact, claiming poems were published without his consent.
Feels shamefaced when confronted by Anne about the implications of the sonnets and his reputation.
Insists family behave formally for the Earl’s visit, strictly controlling interactions.
Excitedly brings news about the Earl of Southampton’s visit, showing engagement and social awareness.
Claims the sonnets were published illegally and without his consent, indicating awareness of reputational risks and controlling information.
Seemingly unaware or unprepared for Anne’s perspective and the impact the sonnets’ publication has had on their family reputation, showing a blind spot.
Plans and organizes the meeting with the Earl by instructing the family on how to behave, demonstrating foresight and social skill.
Appears shame-faced and somewhat defensive when confronted by Anne about the personal implications of his writings, suggesting a lack of emotional readiness or tact.
Buckles to superior rank and says nothing when Sir Thomas Lucy demands an introduction, despite being taken aback.
Responds to Southampton's praise with modesty and self-reflection rather than arrogance.
Admits being snubbed repeatedly by Sir Thomas Lucy without displaying overt resentment or anger.
Allows Southampton's harsh but affectionate critique without defensiveness, showing openness and vulnerability.
Refers to himself as 'the son of a thief' when contrasted with nobility, revealing honesty but potentially self-deprecating without bitterness.
Is deeply moved and delighted by Southampton's praise, showing awareness of his talent.
Defends himself against Southampton's criticism by denying he has led a small life, showing some self-confidence.
Allows Southampton to repeatedly belittle him and question his stature without strongly asserting himself or countering the argument effectively.
Shares a story about his father being fined for avoiding church due to debts, showing openness and a touch of humor.
Laughs and drinks with Southampton, showing camaraderie and friendly interaction.
Reflects on the suspicion he faces despite his merit, revealing vulnerability and sincerity.
Mentions paying twenty pounds for a Coat of Arms, indicating concern for social status.
Responds to Southampton about criticism from Jonson with a somewhat defensive attitude.
Pays twenty pounds for a Coat of Arms, securing social legitimacy.
Acknowledges surviving when many contemporaries have died, showing resilience.
Shows self-awareness about being 'suspect' despite his merit, indicating insight and humility.
Expresses concern over criticism from Jonson about lacking classical education.
Hesitates to write again despite encouragement, demonstrating doubt or insecurity.
Misinterprets Southampton's ambiguous responses and hopeful feelings, failing to pick up on the changed atmosphere and emotional cues.
Maintains a dignified composure despite being emotionally crushed by Southampton's rejection.
Stands very still watching the Southampton procession silently; does not engage or comment.
Works hard with Douglas in the garden; engages in a sincere, reflective conversation about people vs. flowers showing empathy and hope.
Stands very still watching the procession go, silent with his family as there is nothing to say.
Works hard in the garden to forget, applies himself to physical work with focus and determination.
Engages in reflective, thoughtful conversation about people and flowers, showing philosophical insight.
Responds thoughtfully to Douglas’s questions, demonstrating emotional intelligence and a balanced outlook.
Explodes in anger and defensively insists on his contributions and sacrifices for the family.
Acknowledges his absence during Hamnet's death and expresses sorrow.
Claims credit for the family’s fortune and fame, showing pride and lack of humility.
Assertively defends his contributions to the family, citing his provision of house, servants, money, and fame through his genius.
Acknowledges his absence during his son's death and rationalizes it based on external circumstances beyond his control.
Clings defensively to his genius and stature when confronted, refusing to soften his stance despite family tension.
Fails to anticipate the emotional impact or consequences of his defense, allowing Judith to provoke a confrontation that undermines him.
Expresses deep personal vulnerability admitting his soul is empty and that he is frightened and alone after the theatre fire and loss of his son.
Listens silently as Susanna offers comfort and encouragement, showing openness to his family’s support.
Visits Judith at night and apologizes, showing attempt at reconciliation and sensitivity to family grief.
Encourages Judith to write again and offers to teach her, indicating belief in her potential and support.
Gently challenges Judith’s self-hate and tries to reframe her grief and blame regarding the death of her twin.
Determines to begin again after the theatre burns and aims to write his greatest play and open another theatre.
Reflects inwardly but finds nothing in his soul, admits to being barren and frightened, and declares he will never write again.
Offers to teach Judith to write, attempting to support and uplift her despite their strained relationship.
Accepts Judith’s expression of deep self-hatred and grief without correcting or strongly challenging her, showing some passivity.
Acknowledges his shortcomings as a gardener and expresses love rather than ambition will grow in the garden.
Smiles at Anne's offer to help and works together with her on the garden.
Says goodnight to Anne and accepts her invitation to stay with her for comfort.
Hosts his lawyer Francis Collins warmly, offers wine, toasts to his family and grandchildren, and speaks with evident happiness about Judith's marriage and provisions for family.
Shows affectionate regard for his daughter Judith and new son-in-law Tom Quiney, actively making provisions in his will including hopes for future grandchildren.
Amends his Will thoughtfully to include his new son-in-law and ensure provisions for his grandchildren, showing careful planning and foresight.
Expresses confidence about Anne's survival and toughness, indicating practical knowledge and emotional intelligence.
Demonstrates happiness and sociability in inviting his lawyer in and offering wine, reflecting ease and social skill.
Specifies a thoughtful gift of a piece of furniture intended to carry sentimental value for Anne, showing foresight and emotional intelligence.
Displays confidence and a happy demeanor while discussing his intentions, suggesting self-assurance in his plans.
Makes a public speech at his daughter Judith's wedding, skillfully using humor and honesty to engage the crowd and balance serious and lighthearted tones.
Acknowledges the family’s flaws openly, demonstrating self-awareness and candidness in front of a community gathering.
Confronts Sir Thomas Lucy calmly and with wit, explaining the complexity and success of his theater business, showing pride but also a sense of dedication to his work and those involved.
Despite being treated with scorn and pity by others, including Sir Thomas Lucy's insults, Will responds without malice and with composed assertiveness.
Confidently confronts Sir Thomas Lucy, articulating the complexity and success of running a large theatre business, demonstrating knowledge of logistics, politics, and management.
Engages in verbal sparring that exposes his business acumen and defends his professional achievements despite social downfall.
Carefully cuts a quill nib with skill and concentration, producing a beautiful nib to write with.
Writes a few words with the quill, showing some proficiency in writing.
Focuses on emotional remembrance and imagination rather than practical or external action in the scene.
Reflects on the loss of his son Hamnet with visible grief and acknowledges the emotional energy his son gave him for writing.
Visits Hamnet’s grave and contemplates the deaths of other children nearby, showing sensitivity and sorrow.
Shares a somber conversation with Susanna about the quick and tragic death of Hamnet, showing openness and emotional availability.
Thanks Judith for coming and shows concern about her new home
Visits Hamnet’s grave and openly acknowledges his grief
Swallows painfully when Judith mentions her husband’s shame
Mentions the plague and closures without engaging further or consoling Anne or Judith
Visits Hamnet’s grave and reads his name in the Parish Register, showing a thoughtful and intentional act amid tragedy.
Engages in a careful conversation with Judith about her life and husband, displaying social awareness and sensitivity.
Acknowledges the impact of the plague on London and closures of theatres, demonstrating knowledge and contextual understanding.
Swallows painfully when Judith mentions the shame, indicating emotional vulnerability and some difficulty in confronting painful memories.
Stares hard at Anne, his heart in torment over Hamnet’s death.
Reaches out his hand to the boy and asks him to stay a moment despite confusion.
Returns home soaked and shivering; his wife Anne looks on him with pity and love.
Shares a candid and sincere conversation with Ben Jonson about personal losses and hardships.
Walks home a filthy and disheveled figure, soaked through, diminished and shivering, appearing unwell and less capable than his former proud self.
Engages in a thoughtful conversation with Ben Jonson, demonstrating introspection and acceptance of life's hardships.
Attempts to hold on to the boy (symbolic/imagined), showing a struggle to let go and possibly lacking clarity in that moment.
Acknowledges Jonson's praise of having conquered England and returned home victorious, laughs and engages confidently in the conversation despite ill health.
Accepts the recognition that his works are being preserved and that actors and friends respect his genius.
Admits 'Perhaps the second part' when praised for conquering England and returning home, showing humility but confidence in achievements.
Invites his daughter Judith out to the pub gently, asking her not to wake her husband.
Shares his Coat of Arms with friends and pub-goers generously, declaring he has no more need for it and is open about his humble background and family matters.
Makes a self-deprecating, candid remark about his family’s imperfections without embarrassment or defensiveness, responding openly to his daughter's comment.
Admits to taking his wife and daughters for granted and expecting too much of his son; shows self-awareness and remorse.
Looks at Judith who returns his smile; Judith hugs Will and the party begins.
Smiles with deep and special pleasure when Judith talks about writing him a poem and Anne signs the marriage licence.
Jokes with family and friends, including about stealing a theatre and making fun of his own plays.
Gives Hamnet’s pen knife to Judith as a thoughtful, practical gesture.
Smiles peacefully and recites poetry fluently in the garden, demonstrating confidence and mastery in his art.
No indication of confusion, hesitation, or failure; maintains calm composure in family interactions.
